prompt: Facts: Marriage between the respondent (Chandraprakash Kewalchand Jain) and Manjula took place in February 1985.; Manjula died due to 95% burn injuries on July 22, 1985, at the Main Hospital, Akola, Maharashtra, within about six months of marriage.; The incident occurred at the matrimonial home in Akola.; The prosecution alleged that Manjula was subjected to cruelty and harassment by the respondent (husband) and his relatives in connection with demands for dowry (Rs. 50,000, a scooter, refrigerator, television).; Evidence included letters written by the deceased (Exhibits 30, 31, 32) to her parents, expressing her unhappiness and mentioning troubles caused by her husband and in-laws, indirectly linking to demands.; Testimony of the deceased's father (PW1), mother (PW2), and brother (PW3) supported the allegations of dowry demands and harassment.; The defense claimed it was a case of suicide, not related to dowry demands or cruelty.; The Trial Court (Sessions Judge, Akola) acquitted the respondent of charges under Section 306 (Abetment of Suicide) and Section 498A (Cruelty) IPC, finding the letters vague and parental testimony unreliable/insufficiently proximate.; The High Court (Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench) reversed the acquittal for Section 498A IPC, convicting the respondent and sentencing him to 2 years Rigorous Imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 1,000. The High Court upheld the acquittal under Section 306 IPC, finding insufficient evidence for abetment.; The State of Maharashtra appealed to the Supreme Court against the acquittal under Section 306 IPC.; The respondent (accused) filed a cross-appeal against his conviction under Section 498A IPC. | IPC: Section 498A, Section 306, Section 304B (Discussed for context and comparison), Section 107 (Abetment - relevant to Section 306)
